title: Making Tortillas
description: This class teaches the history, cultural significance, techniques, and recipes for making tortillas.

modules.title: History and Cultural Significance of Tortillas

lessons.title: The indigenous origins of tortillas and their significance in Mesoamerican cultures
lessons.info:
Lesson Content: 

In this lesson, we will be learning about the indigenous origins of tortillas and their significance in Mesoamerican cultures. Tortillas have been a staple food in Mesoamerica for thousands of years, dating back to the Aztecs and Mayans. They were made from maize, also known as corn, which was a sacred crop to these cultures. Maize was believed to have been a gift from the gods and was considered a symbol of life and fertility.

The ancient Mesoamericans used various techniques to make their tortillas, including grinding the corn into masa, which was then shaped into a flat disc and cooked on a griddle. Tortillas were not only a food source but also had symbolic significance in religious and social practices. They were used in ceremonies as an offering to the gods, as well as in important life events such as weddings and funerals.

An example of the significance of tortillas in Mesoamerican cultures can be found in the story of the Aztec goddess, Xochiquetzal. It is said that Xochiquetzal was the goddess of fertility and beauty who was also associated with love and flowers. It was believed that she created the first tortilla and taught women how to make them. In honor of Xochiquetzal, women would often decorate their tortillas with flowers and other colorful designs.

Quiz:

1. What is maize also known as?
2. What was the significance of tortillas in religious and social practices?
3. Who is the Aztec goddess associated with tortillas?

Answers:

1. Corn
2. They were used in ceremonies as an offering to the gods, as well as in important life events such as weddings and funerals.
3. Xochiquetzal

lessons.title: The introduction of tortillas to European colonizers and their spread throughout the world
lessons.info:
Lesson Content:

In the 15th century, European colonizers were introduced to the tortilla when they arrived in the New World. Initially, the colonizers found the concept of tortillas bizarre. However, they quickly saw the value in tortilla consumption, which was a source of protein, carbohydrates, and essential nutrients. The Spaniards also found the durability of tortillas appealing, as they could be conserved for days, which meant that they were perfect for long sea voyages.

As a result, the tortilla began to spread throughout the world. The Spanish introduced the tortilla to other European countries, such as France, where they adopted the dish alongside a myriad of other Mexican foods. Tortillas eventually reached the United States, where they became a ubiquitous staple in many households and restaurants across the country.

Overall, the introduction of tortillas to European colonizers was a highly significant moment in culinary history. It led to the spread of this versatile food throughout the world and contributed to the multiculturalism of our culinary landscape.

Quiz:
1. Why did European colonizers initially find the concept of tortillas bizarre?
2. What was one factor that made the Spaniards appreciate the value of tortilla consumption?
3. In what country did the tortilla first develop? 

Answers:
1. They found it bizarre because it was an indigenous food to Mesoamerica.
2. They appreciated that it was a source of protein, carbohydrates, and essential nutrients, and that it could be conserved for long periods.
3. The tortilla first developed in Mesoamerica.

lessons.title: The role of tortillas in Mexican cuisine and the cultural significance of their versatility
lessons.info:
Lesson Content: The role of tortillas in Mexican cuisine and the cultural significance of their versatility

Tortillas are a staple in Mexican cuisine and have played a significant role in the country's history. Their versatility is a defining characteristic of Mexican food; they can be used in dishes ranging from simple tacos to complex dishes like enchiladas and chilaquiles. Tortillas can be made from a variety of grains, including corn or wheat, and come in different shapes and sizes.

The use of tortillas in Mexican cuisine can be traced back to pre-Columbian times when indigenous people used them as a dietary staple. With the arrival of the Spanish in the 16th century, new ingredients were introduced, including wheat and meats like beef and pork. This led to the creation of new dishes like burritos and quesadillas that incorporated both flour and corn tortillas.

The versatility of tortillas extends beyond just their role in Mexican cuisine. They are also symbolic of cultural identity and community. Tortilla making is often a communal activity, with families coming together to create them by hand using traditional techniques that have been passed down for generations. The process of making tortillas is considered to be a bonding activity that reinforces cultural traditions and values.

Quiz:
1. What is a defining characteristic of Mexican food?
2. How have tortillas evolved over time?
 
Answers:
1. A defining characteristic of Mexican food is the versatility of tortillas.
2. With the arrival of the Spanish in the 16th century, new ingredients were introduced, including wheat and meats like beef and pork. This led to the creation of new dishes like burritos and quesadillas that incorporated both flour and corn tortillas.

lessons.title: The symbolism of tortillas in contemporary Mexican-American identity and politics
lessons.info:
In this lesson, we will be exploring the symbolism of tortillas in contemporary Mexican-American identity and politics. Tortillas are not just a food, they are also a symbol of cultural identity and resistance. People of Mexican descent who have immigrated to the United States have brought with them traditions, language, and food. The demand for tortillas has soared, and we see them being sold in mainstream supermarkets. Still, the cultural significance of the tortilla and the role it plays in Mexican-American culture has remained strong.

One example of the symbolism of tortillas is the use of the phrase "tortilla curtain". This concept comes from a novel by T.C. Boyle with the same name, which is a metaphor for the border that separates the United States from Mexico. The tortilla curtain represents the veil of ignorance that prevents people from understanding what happens on the other side. The metaphor has been used to describe the social, economic, and political barriers between Mexicans and Americans, and how they are often misunderstood.

Another example of the symbolism of tortillas is how they have become a symbol of resistance in contemporary Mexican-American politics. In 2012, protests erupted across Mexico when the government raised the price of corn, the main ingredient in tortillas. People took to the streets with signs that read "No m√°s tortillas caras" or "No more expensive tortillas". The protests brought attention to the government's neglect of indigenous and rural communities, who rely on corn and tortillas as a staple food. The symbolism of tortillas as a staple food and cultural symbol was used to express political unrest.

Quiz:
1. What is the "tortilla curtain" metaphor?
Answer: The "tortilla curtain" metaphor is a symbol for the border that separates the United States from Mexico.
2. Why did protests erupt across Mexico in 2012?
Answer: Protests erupted across Mexico in 2012 when the government raised the price of corn, the main ingredient in tortillas.

lessons.title: The impact of globalization on tortilla production and consumption in modern times.
lessons.info:
Lesson Content for "The Impact of Globalization on Tortilla Production and Consumption in Modern Times":

Tortillas are a staple food in many parts of the world and their production and consumption has been impacted by globalization. In recent years, the popularity of Mexican cuisine has grown globally, leading to a high demand for tortillas. This has led to the growth of large-scale tortilla production factories and the use of genetically modified corn to increase production rates. [Source](https://www.npr.org/sections/thesalt/2017/03/01/517802522/how-mexicos-tortilla-crisis-still-hurts-the-poorest)

Moreover, the rise of multinational fast food chains has also significantly impacted the tortilla industry. For example, Taco Bell was founded in the United States in 1962 and has since then expanded worldwide. They use tortillas in many of their menu items, leading to an increased demand for tortillas and even further changes in the industry. [Source](https://www.nytimes.com/2006/02/01/dining/unwrapping-the-taco-bell-gordita.html)

Another impact of globalization on tortilla production is the use of wheat flour instead of corn to make tortillas. This change has led to the creation of hybrid tortillas like the "flour tortilla." These tortillas are not traditionally used in Mexican cuisine but have become a popular option in many parts of the world. [Source](https://www.npr.org/sections/thesalt/2016/09/05/491845807/how-the-flour-tortilla-wrapped-itself-into-the-modern-fertile-crescent)

Quiz:
1. Which fast food chain has impacted the tortilla industry?
Answer: Taco Bell
2. What is a hybrid tortilla?
Answer: A tortilla made with wheat flour instead of corn.

lessons.title: The basic ingredients and equipment needed for tortilla making
lessons.info:
Lesson: Basic Ingredients and Equipment for Tortilla Making

In order to make delicious tortillas, it is important to have the correct ingredients and equipment on hand. The essential ingredients for tortilla making include masa harina (corn flour), water, and salt. Other optional ingredients may include various seasonings for flavor, such as cilantro or chili powder. When shopping for masa harina, it is important to purchase specifically labeled "for tortillas" to ensure the right texture for your tortillas.

In addition to the ingredients, you will also need several pieces of equipment for successful tortilla making. Primarily, you will need a comal (a type of griddle or skillet), a rolling pin, and a tortilla press. A comal provides the perfect flat surface for cooking tortillas, while the rolling pin and tortilla press are used to shape and flatten the masa harina into the perfect round shape. Some other optional equipment may include parchment paper or a tortilla warmer. 

Going forward in your tortilla-making endeavors, be sure to have the proper ingredients and equipment on hand. With these basics, creating perfect tortillas will be a breeze!

Quiz:
1. What are the essential ingredients for tortilla making?
2. What are some optional ingredients for flavor and how should you shop when looking for masa harina?
3. What are the three essential pieces of equipment for tortilla making?
4. What are some other optional pieces of equipment for tortilla making?
Answers:
1. Masa harina, water, salt
2. Optional ingredients vary but may include cilantro or chili powder. Specifically look for masa harina labeled "for tortillas."
3. A comal, a rolling pin, and a tortilla press.
4. Parchment paper or a tortilla warmer.

lessons.title: Techniques for preparing and cooking masa dough
lessons.info:
Welcome to our lesson on Techniques for Preparing and Cooking Masa Dough. Masa dough is an essential ingredient in traditional Mexican cuisine, as it is used in many dishes like tortillas, tamales, and pupusas. 

First, we will begin with preparing the dough. Masa dough is made from masa harina, which is a type of ground corn flour treated with lime. The masa harina is mixed with warm water until it becomes a pliable dough. It's important to let the dough rest for about 30 minutes before using it, so that it can fully hydrate and become easier to work with. 

Now, onto the cooking techniques. After the dough has rested, it's time to shape it into the desired form. For tortillas, the dough can either be shaped by hand or by using a tortilla press. Once the tortillas are shaped, they can be cooked on a hot, dry griddle or comal. It's important to not overcook the tortillas, or they will become hard and difficult to eat.

In summary, preparing and cooking masa dough requires attention to detail and some good old-fashioned elbow grease. By following these techniques, you'll be able to create delicious and authentic Mexican dishes right in your own kitchen. Quiz: 1. What is masa harina? 2. How long should masa dough rest before using it? 3. How can tortillas be shaped? 4. How should tortillas be cooked on the comal? Answers: 1. A type of ground corn flour treated with lime. 2. About 30 minutes. 3. By hand or by using a tortilla press. 4. On a hot, dry griddle or comal, making sure not to overcook them.

lessons.title: Different methods for shaping and rolling tortillas
lessons.info:
Lesson on Different Methods for Shaping and Rolling Tortillas:

In this lesson, we will be discussing the various methods for shaping and rolling tortillas. One of the most common methods is the use of a tortilla press, which is a specialized tool used to flatten masa into thin, round discs. The press is made up of two flat plates that are pressed together to flatten the masa. Once the masa is flattened, it can be cooked on a hot surface, such as a griddle or skillet, until it is crisp and golden brown.

Another popular method for shaping tortillas is to use a rolling pin. To do this, the masa is placed between two sheets of plastic or parchment paper and rolled out to the desired thickness. The rolled out masa is then cut into rounds using a cookie cutter or a knife. The edges are then trimmed to create perfectly round tortillas. Once the tortillas are shaped, they are cooked on a hot surface until they are cooked through and lightly browned.

Overall, there are many different methods for shaping and rolling tortillas, each with their own advantages and disadvantages. Whether you prefer the convenience of a tortilla press or the versatility of a rolling pin, there is no shortage of ways to make these delicious and versatile flatbreads.

Quiz:
1. What is a tortilla press?
2. What is the advantage of using a rolling pin to shape tortillas?
3. How are tortillas cooked once they are shaped and rolled?

Answers:
1. A tortilla press is a specialized tool used to flatten masa into thin, round discs.
2. The advantage of using a rolling pin is that it allows for greater precision and control when shaping the tortillas.
3. Tortillas are cooked on a hot surface, such as a griddle or skillet, until they are cooked through and lightly browned.

lessons.title: Tips for cooking and storing tortillas to maintain their freshness and flavor
lessons.info:
Lesson: Tips for cooking and storing tortillas to maintain their freshness and flavor.

In order to ensure that your tortillas remain as fresh and flavorful as possible, there are several tips and tricks that you can use when cooking and storing them. One thing to keep in mind is that tortillas are best when they are cooked fresh, so it's a good idea to make them right before you plan to use them.

To keep freshly cooked tortillas warm and moist, wrap them in a cloth or towel and store them in a tortilla warmer or a container with a tight-fitting lid. If you don't have a tortilla warmer, you can use a clean kitchen towel or paper towel to wrap the tortillas.

When storing tortillas for later use, it's best to store them in an airtight container in the refrigerator or the freezer. Tortillas will generally keep for up to 2 weeks in the refrigerator and up to 6 months in the freezer. Just be sure to let them come to room temperature before using them.

Quiz:
1. What is the best way to keep freshly cooked tortillas warm and moist?
2. How long will tortillas generally keep in the refrigerator?
3. Can you freeze tortillas? If so, how long will they keep in the freezer?
Answers:
1. Wrap them in a cloth or towel and store them in a tortilla warmer or a container with a tight-fitting lid.
2. Tortillas will generally keep for up to 2 weeks in the refrigerator.
3. Yes, tortillas can be frozen. They will generally keep for up to 6 months in the freezer.

lessons.title: Recipe variations for flavored and colored tortillas.
lessons.info:
In this lesson, we will be exploring recipe variations for flavored and colored tortillas. Tortillas are a versatile food item that you can play with by adding various spices and herbs to enhance their taste and aroma or natural colorings to make them more visually appealing. 

To make flavoured tortillas, you can add ingredients such as garlic, onion, parsley or cilantro to the masa dough to create a savoury and fragrant addition to the tortilla. You can use cumin, smoked paprika, or chilli powder to create spiced tortillas that add a kick of heat. Add in some cheese and jalapeno peppers to your dough to make cheese and jalapeno tortillas or sun-dried tomatoes to make tomato-flavoured tortillas. 

To make colored tortillas, you can use natural colourings. Cilantro makes green-colored tortillas, and beet juice makes pink tortillas. These colors not only make your food look appealing, but they also provide various nutrients and health benefits.

Practice problem: 
What ingredients can be added to masa dough to make green coloured tortillas?
Solution: 
Cilantro can be added to masa dough to make green-coloured tortillas.

In summary, creating various flavours and colours in tortillas offers plenty of room for creativity. Whether you want to try different spices and herbs, adding cheese or jalapeno, or make visually appealing tortillas with vibrant natural colors, the possibilities for experimentation are endless.
